WorkItem.ClosedComment: The memory leak was fixed in the January 2009 release.
WorkItem.Description:
I think there's a memory leak in the DatePicker of WPF Toolkit (October 2008 Release).
 
I've attached a simple WPF application project (using VS2008SP1) to demonstrate this problem. Further, a profiler is needed to see what's going on inside (I'm using .NET Memory Profiler 3.1).
 
Basically, in the application there are two windows: Window1 and ChildWindow1. In the Window1, there's a Button to open ChildWindow1. In the ChildWindow1, there's a DatePicker. Everytime ChildWindow1 is opened and closed (using the Window1's Button), its instances remain in the memory (indicates a memory leak) since there's always a reference that hold to the DatePicker. If I remove the DatePicker from the ChildWindow1, the ChildWindow1 is released appropriately. Also, when I open the ChildWindow1 for the first time, it shows up a little bit longer than I expected (compared to other simple controls). I presume there's also a performance issue in it.
WorkItem.Summary: DatePicker's Memory Leak and (A Bit) Display Performance Issue

Comments.Message: The bug is probably the one I reported about the VSM - http://www.codeplex.com/wpf/WorkItem/View.aspx?WorkItemId=7906 - which the DataGrid and DateTimePicker/Calendar use.

Yes, I've just known if it's related to mine and it's just published here: http://www.codeplex.com/wpf/Wiki/View.aspx?title=VSM%20Memory%20Leak.

Thanks!

Yes this does look like the earlier reported issue and it will be fixed in the v1 release.
Thanks for your report.
